results.title: Seinfeld. Vol. 05
results.brief_description: Features 3 “Seinfeld” episodes screened between 1990-1997. “The Busboy”; George tries to make it up to a busboy he has fired while Elaine risks life and limb to get rid of a visiting boyfriend. “The Baby Shower”; Kramer cons Jerry into having an illegal cable link. The day they instal the cable Elaine is hosting a baby shower in Jerry’s apartment. One of the guests previously dated George and humilated him on a date. “The Hamptons”; Produced by Tom Gammill and Max Pross. Jerry, Elaine, Kramer, George and George’s new girlfriend spend an eventful weekend at the holiday house of friends with an “ugly” baby. Everyone except George sees his new girlfriend baking topless, Kramer stumbles across a catch of lobsters, and George is caught in an embarrassing situation due to “shrinkage”.

results.title: Segmentation: the annelid worms
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 3. Animal life”

Describes the structure and functions of the nervous, digestive and reproductive systems of the earthworm. Shows that the segmented annelid worm body represents an important evolutionary development.
Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Seen one, seen 'em all
results.brief_description: This program looks at media representation of ethnic and minority groups. The video uses a zany quiz show format to raise questions about ethnic stereotyping using examples from advertising. Both the video and its accompanying study guide provide a launching point for classroom discussion, activity and further study, suitable for a wide range of age groups.

results.title: Seen but not heard
results.creator_credit: New South Wales Film Corporation, Barbara A. Chobocky and Gillian Coote
results.brief_description: The International Year of the Child presented children with the opportunity to articulate their views on a variety of issues. Here they consider what their rights are, how they deal with them, and also how they resolve their grievances.

results.title: Seen but not heard
results.brief_description: Seen but not Heard probes the often-hidden feelings, attitudes and beliefs of kids in the formative and volatile stages of the early teens. It is a time when privacy, independence and experimentation create a separate world for young people; a world into which adults only rarely get a glimpse. For adolescents, it is a provocative examination of their own lives. For parents, it is an eye-opening insight into the lives of their children. For younger children it is a hint of things to come.

results.title: Seeing with the camera
results.creator_credit: Sandra Ostertag, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, CBS, KOCE-TV (Television station : Huntington Beach, Calif.) and Coast Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Photographic vision”.
Demonstrates the technical differences between human and camera vision, and discusses the personal vision of the photographer. Eileen Cowin and Grant Mudford describe and demonstrate their approaches to photographic interpretation.

results.title: Seeing through commercials
results.creator_credit: Barr Films, Larry Stein and Ruth Arens
results.brief_description: Designed to alert younger children to the techniques and motivations behind television commercials. Shows how close-up shots, camera angles, lighting and special effects can make products seem bigger and more exciting than they really are, and points out how the narration in commercials can be misleading. Also notes how important product information and disclaimers are often included very briefly and subtly at the end of a commercial. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
